1.General: Abraham was now very old, and the Lord had blessed him in every way.
1.Non-Denominational: Abraham was now very old, and the Lord had blessed him in every way.
1.Baptist: Sets the stage: Abraham is elderly and blessed by God, focusing now on securing Isaac's future.
1.Catholic: Describes Abraham's advanced age and the comprehensive blessings bestowed upon him by God, setting the context for ensuring the covenant's continuation through Isaac.
1.Methodist: Highlights Abraham's advanced age and God's abundant blessings, transitioning to his concern for Isaac's lineage.
1.Lutheran: Abraham is old and acknowledged as blessed by God in all things.
1.Presbyterian: Notes Abraham's old age and God's comprehensive blessing upon him, leading into his concern for covenant continuity.
1.Pentecostal: Abraham is old and blessed; focuses on Isaac's future.
1.Episcopalian/Anglican: Notes Abraham's old age and God's comprehensive blessing upon him, setting the scene for finding a wife for Isaac.
1.Orthodox: Establishes Abraham's advanced age and God's manifold blessings as the context for ensuring Isaac's marriage.
1.Other: Abraham was now very old, and the Lord had blessed him in every way.
1.Prefer not to say: Abraham was now very old, and the Lord had blessed him in every way.

2.General: He said to the chief servant in his household, the one in charge of all that he had, 'Put your hand under my thigh.'
2.Non-Denominational: He said to the chief servant in his household, the one in charge of all that he had, 'Put your hand under my thigh.'
2.Baptist: Abraham instructs his most trusted servant (likely Eliezer) to take a solemn oath regarding a crucial mission.
2.Catholic: Abraham instructs his senior servant (steward of his entire household) to prepare for a solemn oath, signified by placing his hand under Abraham's thigh (a gesture possibly related to descendants/covenant).
2.Methodist: Abraham entrusts his chief servant with a vital task, initiating a solemn oath.
2.Lutheran: Abraham commands his chief servant to take a solemn oath (placing hand under thigh).
2.Presbyterian: Abraham commissions his chief servant, initiating a solemn oath (hand under thigh) for a critical task.
2.Pentecostal: Abraham instructs his chief servant to take a serious oath.
2.Episcopalian/Anglican: Abraham instructs his chief servant (steward) to make a solemn oath, signified by placing his hand under Abraham's thigh.
2.Orthodox: Abraham charges his chief servant with a critical mission, initiating it with a solemn oath gesture.
2.Other: He said to the chief servant in his household, the one in charge of all that he had, 'Put your hand under my thigh.'
2.Prefer not to say: He said to the chief servant in his household, the one in charge of all that he had, 'Put your hand under my thigh.'

3.General: 'I want you to swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living,'
3.Non-Denominational: 'I want you to swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living,'
3.Baptist: The oath's core: secure a wife for Isaac from Abraham's kin, not from the local Canaanites, invoking God's supreme authority.
3.Catholic: Abraham requires the servant to swear by the supreme authority of God ('God of heaven and earth') not to choose a wife for Isaac from the local Canaanite population, preserving religious purity.
3.Methodist: The oath specifies avoiding Canaanite wives for Isaac, ensuring preservation of faith and covenant lineage.
3.Lutheran: Abraham makes the servant swear by God Almighty not to take a Canaanite wife for Isaac.
3.Presbyterian: Abraham demands an oath by God Almighty to ensure Isaac does not marry a Canaanite, preserving covenant distinction.
3.Pentecostal: The oath: Isaac must not marry a Canaanite woman.
3.Episcopalian/Anglican: Abraham makes the servant swear by God not to choose a wife for Isaac from the Canaanites among whom they lived.
3.Orthodox: Abraham demands an oath invoking God's universal authority, forbidding marriage for Isaac among the Canaanites to maintain covenant faithfulness.
3.Other: 'I want you to swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living,'
3.Prefer not to say: 'I want you to swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living,'

4.General: 'but will go to my country and my own relatives and get a wife for my son Isaac.'
4.Non-Denominational: 'but will go to my country and my own relatives and get a wife for my son Isaac.'
4.Baptist: The mission objective: travel to Abraham's homeland (Mesopotamia) and find a wife for Isaac from his extended family.
4.Catholic: The positive command: the servant must journey back to Abraham's homeland and extended family (in Mesopotamia) to find a suitable wife for Isaac.
4.Methodist: The servant's mission is to find a wife for Isaac from Abraham's relatives in his native land.
4.Lutheran: Instead, the servant must travel to Abraham's homeland and relatives to find Isaac a wife.
4.Presbyterian: The positive requirement: the servant must travel to Abraham's homeland (Mesopotamia) and select a wife from his relatives.
4.Pentecostal: The servant must find a wife for Isaac from Abraham's relatives.
4.Episcopalian/Anglican: The servant is instructed to go instead to Abraham's homeland and relatives to find a wife for Isaac.
4.Orthodox: The specific task: the servant must journey to Abraham's ancestral homeland to select a wife for Isaac from among their kin.
4.Other: 'but will go to my country and my own relatives and get a wife for my son Isaac.'
4.Prefer not to say: 'but will go to my country and my own relatives and get a wife for my son Isaac.'

5.General: The servant asked him, 'What if the woman is unwilling to come back with me to this land? Shall I then take your son back to the country you came from?'
5.Non-Denominational: The servant asked him, 'What if the woman is unwilling to come back with me to this land? Shall I then take your son back to the country you came from?'
5.Baptist: The servant raises a practical objection/question: What if the chosen woman refuses to leave her home? Should Isaac go there instead?
5.Catholic: The servant raises a crucial practical question: What if the chosen woman refuses to relocate to Canaan? Should Isaac then be taken back to Mesopotamia?
5.Methodist: The servant prudently raises a potential obstacle: the woman's unwillingness to relocate, and asks about taking Isaac back.
5.Lutheran: The servant raises a practical concern: What if the woman will not come? Should Isaac go back?
5.Presbyterian: The servant raises a pertinent question regarding the woman's potential unwillingness to leave her homeland.
5.Pentecostal: The servant asks a practical question about the woman's willingness to move.
5.Episcopalian/Anglican: The servant raises a practical concern: What if the woman refuses to come to Canaan? Should Isaac go there?
5.Orthodox: The servant prudently inquires about the contingency of the woman refusing to leave her homeland.
5.Other: The servant asked him, 'What if the woman is unwilling to come back with me to this land? Shall I then take your son back to the country you came from?'
5.Prefer not to say: The servant asked him, 'What if the woman is unwilling to come back with me to this land? Shall I then take your son back to the country you came from?'

6.General: 'Make sure that you do not take my son back there,' Abraham said.
6.Non-Denominational: 'Make sure that you do not take my son back there,' Abraham said.
6.Baptist: Abraham adamantly forbids Isaac returning to Mesopotamia, emphasizing residence in the Promised Land.
6.Catholic: Abraham strictly forbids taking Isaac back to Mesopotamia, emphasizing that Isaac must remain in Canaan, the land promised by God.
6.Methodist: Abraham explicitly forbids taking Isaac back, prioritizing Isaac's presence in the Promised Land.
6.Lutheran: Abraham strictly forbids taking Isaac back to Mesopotamia; Isaac must stay in Canaan.
6.Presbyterian: Abraham emphatically forbids Isaac's return to Mesopotamia, stressing the importance of remaining in the Promised Land.
6.Pentecostal: Abraham strictly forbids taking Isaac back.
6.Episcopalian/Anglican: Abraham strictly forbids the servant from taking Isaac back to Mesopotamia.
6.Orthodox: Abraham absolutely forbids Isaac's return to Mesopotamia, underscoring the necessity of remaining in the land of promise.
6.Other: 'Make sure that you do not take my son back there,' Abraham said.
6.Prefer not to say: 'Make sure that you do not take my son back there,' Abraham said.

7.General: 'The Lord, the God of heaven, who brought me out of my father's household and my native land and who spoke to me and promised me on oath, saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land'—he will send his angel before you so that you can get a wife for my son from there.'
7.Non-Denominational: 'The Lord, the God of heaven, who brought me out of my father's household and my native land and who spoke to me and promised me on oath, saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land'—he will send his angel before you so that you can get a wife for my son from there.'
7.Baptist: Abraham expresses faith in God's guidance, recalling God's promises and assuring the servant of divine/angelic assistance in the mission.
7.Catholic: Abraham expresses strong faith, recalling God's call, promises (especially the land grant confirmed by oath), and assures the servant that God will send His angel to ensure the mission's success.
7.Methodist: Abraham affirms his trust in God's past faithfulness and promises, assuring the servant of God's angelic guidance.
7.Lutheran: Abraham expresses faith in God's promise and providence, believing God will send His angel to guide the servant.
7.Presbyterian: Abraham bases his confidence on God's past faithfulness and sworn covenant promise, assuring the servant of divine (angelic) guidance.
7.Pentecostal: Abraham expresses faith that God, who promised the land, will guide the servant.
7.Episcopalian/Anglican: Abraham expresses faith based on God's past actions and promises, assuring the servant that God will send an angel ahead to ensure success.
7.Orthodox: Abraham voices his unwavering faith, recalling God's guidance and sworn promises, and assures the servant of divine (angelic) assistance.
7.Other: 'The Lord, the God of heaven, who brought me out of my father's household and my native land and who spoke to me and promised me on oath, saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land'—he will send his angel before you so that you can get a wife for my son from there.'
7.Prefer not to say: 'The Lord, the God of heaven, who brought me out of my father's household and my native land and who spoke to me and promised me on oath, saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land'—he will send his angel before you so that you can get a wife for my son from there.'

8.General: 'If the woman is unwilling to come back with you, then you will be released from this oath of mine. Only do not take my son back there.'
8.Non-Denominational: 'If the woman is unwilling to come back with you, then you will be released from this oath of mine. Only do not take my son back there.'
8.Baptist: Abraham provides a release clause: if the woman refuses, the servant is freed from the oath, but Isaac must still not return.
8.Catholic: Abraham provides an escape clause: if, despite divine help, the woman refuses, the servant is released from his oath. However, the prohibition against taking Isaac back remains absolute.
8.Methodist: Abraham releases the servant from the oath if the woman refuses, but reiterates the primary condition: Isaac stays in Canaan.
8.Lutheran: If the woman refuses, the servant is released from the oath, but Isaac must not be taken back.
8.Presbyterian: Abraham releases the servant from the oath if the woman is unwilling, but reiterates the absolute prohibition on Isaac leaving Canaan.
8.Pentecostal: If the woman refuses, the servant is free from the oath, but Isaac cannot go back.
8.Episcopalian/Anglican: Abraham clarifies that if the woman refuses to come, the servant will be released from the oath, but Isaac must absolutely not return there.
8.Orthodox: Abraham provides for the possibility of failure, releasing the servant from the oath if the woman refuses, while firmly maintaining Isaac must not leave Canaan.
8.Other: 'If the woman is unwilling to come back with you, then you will be released from this oath of mine. Only do not take my son back there.'
8.Prefer not to say: 'If the woman is unwilling to come back with you, then you will be released from this oath of mine. Only do not take my son back there.'

9.General: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of his master Abraham and swore an oath to him concerning this matter.
9.Non-Denominational: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of his master Abraham and swore an oath to him concerning this matter.
9.Baptist: The servant formally takes the oath as instructed.
9.Catholic: The servant performs the oath-taking ritual (hand under thigh) and formally swears to fulfill Abraham's instructions.
9.Methodist: The servant formally commits to the mission by taking the prescribed oath.
9.Lutheran: The servant performs the ritual and swears the oath.
9.Presbyterian: The servant formally takes the oath as commanded.
9.Episcopalian/Anglican: The servant completes the oath-taking ceremony, placing his hand under Abraham's thigh and swearing.
9.Orthodox: The servant formally binds himself by the oath as instructed by Abraham.
9.Other: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of his master Abraham and swore an oath to him concerning this matter.
9.Prefer not to say: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of his master Abraham and swore an oath to him concerning this matter.

10.General: Then the servant left, taking with him ten of his master's camels loaded with all kinds of good things from his master. He set out for Aram Naharaim and made his way to the town of Nahor.
10.Non-Denominational: Then the servant left, taking with him ten of his master's camels loaded with all kinds of good things from his master. He set out for Aram Naharaim and made his way to the town of Nahor.
10.Baptist: The servant departs, well-equipped with camels and valuable gifts (bride-price/dowry), heading towards Nahor's town in Mesopotamia.
10.Catholic: The servant departs on his mission, taking a substantial caravan (ten camels) laden with valuable gifts from Abraham (reflecting Abraham's wealth and seriousness). He travels to Aram Naharaim (Mesopotamia), specifically to Nahor's city.
10.Methodist: The servant begins the journey, equipped with resources and gifts, traveling towards Abraham's relatives.
10.Lutheran: The servant departs with ten camels and valuable gifts, traveling to Nahor's town in Aram Naharaim (Mesopotamia).
10.Presbyterian: The servant departs, well-provisioned with ten camels and gifts, traveling to Nahor's town in Aram Naharaim.
10.Pentecostal: The servant departs with gifts for the journey to Nahor's town.
10.Episcopalian/Anglican: The servant departs with ten camels and many valuable gifts from Abraham, heading for Nahor's town in Aram Naharaim (Mesopotamia).
10.Orthodox: The servant commences his journey with a well-equipped caravan, including valuable gifts, heading towards the city of Nahor in Mesopotamia.
10.Other: Then the servant left, taking with him ten of his master's camels loaded with all kinds of good things from his master. He set out for Aram Naharaim and made his way to the town of Nahor.
10.Prefer not to say: Then the servant left, taking with him ten of his master's camels loaded with all kinds of good things from his master. He set out for Aram Naharaim and made his way to the town of Nahor.

11.General: He had the camels kneel down near the well outside the town; it was toward evening, the time the women go out to draw water.
11.Non-Denominational: He had the camels kneel down near the well outside the town; it was toward evening, the time the women go out to draw water.
11.Baptist: The servant arrives and strategically positions himself at the town well in the evening, knowing this is when women gather.
11.Catholic: Upon arrival, the servant strategically waits by the town well in the evening, the customary time and place for women to draw water, hoping for a divine encounter.
11.Methodist: The servant strategically arrives at the well during the time women traditionally gather water.
11.Lutheran: He arrives at the town well in the evening, the time women come to draw water.
11.Presbyterian: The servant strategically arrives at the well at the time women draw water.
11.Pentecostal: He waits by the well at the usual time for women to draw water.
11.Episcopalian/Anglican: He strategically has the camels kneel by the well outside the town in the evening, the time women typically come to draw water.
11.Orthodox: The servant strategically positions himself by the well at the customary time for women to gather, awaiting guidance.
11.Other: He had the camels kneel down near the well outside the town; it was toward evening, the time the women go out to draw water.
11.Prefer not to say: He had the camels kneel down near the well outside the town; it was toward evening, the time the women go out to draw water.

12.General: Then he prayed, 'Lord, God of my master Abraham, make me successful today, and show kindness to my master Abraham.'
12.Non-Denominational: Then he prayed, 'Lord, God of my master Abraham, make me successful today, and show kindness to my master Abraham.'
12.Baptist: The servant prays for success, invoking God's relationship with Abraham and asking for divine favor (kindness/hesed) upon his master.
12.Catholic: The servant prays earnestly, invoking God specifically as the God of Abraham, asking for success in his mission that day and for God to show covenant faithfulness ('kindness', Hebrew: hesed) to Abraham.
12.Methodist: The servant seeks God's guidance through prayer, asking for success and invoking God's covenant faithfulness (kindness) to Abraham.
12.Lutheran: The servant prays to Yahweh, the God of Abraham, asking for success and kindness (hesed) towards his master.
12.Presbyterian: The servant prays to Yahweh, God of Abraham, seeking success and appealing to God's covenant loyalty (hesed) toward Abraham.
12.Pentecostal: The servant prays for God's guidance and success.
12.Episcopalian/Anglican: The servant prays to the Lord, God of Abraham, asking for success that day and for God to show kindness (covenant loyalty, hesed) to Abraham.
12.Orthodox: The servant begins with prayer, addressing God as the God of Abraham and seeking success based on God's covenant faithfulness (hesed) to his master.
12.Other: Then he prayed, 'Lord, God of my master Abraham, make me successful today, and show kindness to my master Abraham.'
12.Prefer not to say: Then he prayed, 'Lord, God of my master Abraham, make me successful today, and show kindness to my master Abraham.'

13.General: 'See, I am standing beside this spring, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.'
13.Non-Denominational: 'See, I am standing beside this spring, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.'
13.Baptist: He states his position and observes the expected arrival of the young women.
13.Catholic: He sets the scene for his specific request within the prayer, noting his location and the arrival of the townswomen.
13.Methodist: He outlines the situation to God in his prayer.
13.Lutheran: He lays out the situation in his prayer: he is by the spring as the women arrive.
13.Presbyterian: He sets the context for his specific request in prayer.
13.Pentecostal: He describes the scene in his prayer.
13.Episcopalian/Anglican: He states his location by the spring as the townswomen approach.
13.Orthodox: He describes the setting of his prayer, awaiting the arrival of the women.
13.Other: 'See, I am standing beside this spring, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.'
13.Prefer not to say: 'See, I am standing beside this spring, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.'

14.General: 'May it be that when I say to a young woman, 'Please let down your jar that I may have a drink,' and she says, 'Drink, and I'll water your camels too'—let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown kindness to my master.'
14.Non-Denominational: 'May it be that when I say to a young woman, 'Please let down your jar that I may have a drink,' and she says, 'Drink, and I'll water your camels too'—let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown kindness to my master.'
14.Baptist: The servant proposes a specific sign: the woman who offers water not only to him but also spontaneously to his camels will be God's chosen one.
14.Catholic: He proposes a specific, twofold sign of divine guidance: the young woman who responds to his request for water by offering it to him AND proactively offering to water his camels will be the one designated by God for Isaac. This sign tests for generosity and initiative.
14.Methodist: He asks God for a specific sign involving exceptional hospitality (watering the camels) to identify the chosen woman.
14.Lutheran: He requests a specific sign: the woman who offers water to him and spontaneously offers to water his camels is the one chosen by God.
14.Presbyterian: He proposes a specific sign involving extraordinary generosity (offering water to him and his camels) as confirmation of God's choice and faithfulness (hesed).
14.Pentecostal: He asks for a specific sign: the woman who offers water to him and his camels.
14.Episcopalian/Anglican: He asks God for a specific sign: the woman who not only gives him a drink but also offers to water his ten camels will be the one chosen for Isaac, confirming God's kindness (hesed).
14.Orthodox: He proposes a specific test involving extraordinary hospitality—offering water to him and his camels—as the sign identifying God's chosen bride for Isaac.
14.Other: 'May it be that when I say to a young woman, 'Please let down your jar that I may have a drink,' and she says, 'Drink, and I'll water your camels too'—let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown kindness to my master.'
14.Prefer not to say: 'May it be that when I say to a young woman, 'Please let down your jar that I may have a drink,' and she says, 'Drink, and I'll water your camels too'—let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown kindness to my master.'

15.General: Before he even finished praying, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel son of Milkah, who was the wife of Abraham's brother Nahor.
15.Non-Denominational: Before he even finished praying, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel son of Milkah, who was the wife of Abraham's brother Nahor.
15.Baptist: God's immediate answer: Rebekah appears before the prayer is even finished, identified as belonging to Abraham's relatives.
15.Catholic: God answers swiftly: even before the servant finishes praying, Rebekah arrives. The text explicitly identifies her as the granddaughter of Abraham's brother Nahor, fulfilling the kinship requirement.
15.Methodist: God provides an immediate answer to the prayer as Rebekah, Abraham's relative, appears.
15.Lutheran: God answers immediately: Rebekah, daughter of Bethuel (Nahor's son), appears before the prayer ends.
15.Presbyterian: God answers the prayer immediately. Rebekah, who is from Abraham's family line, arrives.
15.Pentecostal: God answers the prayer quickly as Rebekah arrives.
15.Episcopalian/Anglican: God's answer is immediate: before the servant finishes praying, Rebekah arrives, identified as the granddaughter of Abraham's brother Nahor.
15.Orthodox: God responds immediately to the prayer: Rebekah, identified as part of Abraham's extended family, arrives at the well.
15.Other: Before he even finished praying, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel son of Milkah, who was the wife of Abraham's brother Nahor.
15.Prefer not to say: Before he even finished praying, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel son of Milkah, who was the wife of Abraham's brother Nahor.

16.General: The woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had ever slept with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar and came up again.
16.Non-Denominational: The woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had ever slept with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar and came up again.
16.Baptist: Describes Rebekah's positive attributes (beauty, virginity) and her actions at the well.
16.Catholic: Describes Rebekah's qualities: exceptional beauty and virginity (important for the chosen lineage). It narrates her actions of drawing water.
16.Methodist: Highlights Rebekah's beauty and purity, describing her task at the spring.
16.Lutheran: Rebekah is described as beautiful and a virgin. She proceeds to draw water.
16.Presbyterian: Describes Rebekah as beautiful and a virgin, suitable for the covenant line.
16.Episcopalian/Anglican: Describes Rebekah as very beautiful and a virgin, emphasizing her suitability.
16.Orthodox: Notes Rebekah's physical beauty and status as a virgin, highlighting her suitability.
16.Other: The woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had ever slept with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar and came up again.
16.Prefer not to say: The woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had ever slept with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar and came up again.

17.General: The servant hurried to meet her and said, 'Please give me a little water from your jar.'
17.Non-Denominational: The servant hurried to meet her and said, 'Please give me a little water from your jar.'
17.Baptist: The servant initiates the test, politely requesting water from Rebekah.
17.Catholic: The servant approaches Rebekah and initiates the test proposed in his prayer, politely requesting a drink.
17.Methodist: The servant approaches Rebekah to initiate the test he proposed in prayer.
17.Lutheran: The servant approaches Rebekah and politely asks for water, initiating the test.
17.Presbyterian: The servant initiates the test by politely asking Rebekah for water.
17.Pentecostal: The servant asks Rebekah for water.
17.Episcopalian/Anglican: The servant hurries to meet her and makes his request for water, initiating the sign.
17.Orthodox: The servant approaches Rebekah and politely requests water, beginning the proposed test.
17.Other: The servant hurried to meet her and said, 'Please give me a little water from your jar.'
17.Prefer not to say: The servant hurried to meet her and said, 'Please give me a little water from your jar.'

18.General: 'Drink, my lord,' she said, and quickly lowered the jar to her hands and gave him a drink.
18.Non-Denominational: 'Drink, my lord,' she said, and quickly lowered the jar to her hands and gave him a drink.
18.Baptist: Rebekah readily complies with the first part of the sign, offering him water graciously.
18.Catholic: Rebekah responds immediately and courteously ('Drink, my lord'), fulfilling the first part of the servant's requested sign.
18.Methodist: Rebekah responds promptly and hospitably, fulfilling the first part of the sign.
18.Lutheran: Rebekah responds quickly and politely, offering him a drink.
18.Presbyterian: Rebekah immediately and graciously offers him water.
18.Episcopalian/Anglican: Rebekah responds immediately and courteously, offering him a drink and fulfilling the first part of the sign.
18.Orthodox: Rebekah responds swiftly and graciously, offering him water as requested.
18.Other: 'Drink, my lord,' she said, and quickly lowered the jar to her hands and gave him a drink.
18.Prefer not to say: 'Drink, my lord,' she said, and quickly lowered the jar to her hands and gave him a drink.

19.General: After she had given him a drink, she said, 'I'll draw water for your camels too, until they have had enough to drink.'
19.Non-Denominational: After she had given him a drink, she said, 'I'll draw water for your camels too, until they have had enough to drink.'
19.Baptist: Rebekah goes above and beyond, spontaneously offering to water the camels, fulfilling the second, crucial part of the sign.
19.Catholic: Rebekah then spontaneously offers to draw water for all his camels as well, completely fulfilling the specific sign the servant had prayed for, demonstrating exceptional generosity and diligence.
19.Methodist: Rebekah initiates the second part of the sign herself, offering the strenuous task of watering the camels.
19.Lutheran: Rebekah spontaneously offers to draw water for the camels as well, fulfilling the second part of the sign.
19.Presbyterian: Rebekah proactively offers the considerable labor of watering the camels, fulfilling the specific sign requested.
19.Pentecostal: Rebekah offers to water the camels also, fulfilling the sign.
19.Episcopalian/Anglican: Crucially, Rebekah then offers to draw water for the camels as well, fulfilling the second, more demanding part of the sign.
19.Orthodox: Rebekah then goes beyond the request and offers to water the camels, fulfilling the specific sign the servant had sought.
19.Other: After she had given him a drink, she said, 'I'll draw water for your camels too, until they have had enough to drink.'
19.Prefer not to say: After she had given him a drink, she said, 'I'll draw water for your camels too, until they have had enough to drink.'

20.General: So she quickly emptied her jar into the trough, ran back to the well to draw more water, and drew enough for all his camels.
20.Non-Denominational: So she quickly emptied her jar into the trough, ran back to the well to draw more water, and drew enough for all his camels.
20.Baptist: Demonstrates Rebekah's energy and commitment as she diligently waters all ten camels.
20.Catholic: Describes Rebekah's energetic and diligent actions as she quickly draws sufficient water for all ten camels, a laborious task.
20.Methodist: Highlights Rebekah's industriousness and generosity in action.
20.Lutheran: Rebekah acts quickly and diligently to water all the camels.
20.Presbyterian: Rebekah demonstrates diligence and generosity by quickly drawing enough water for all the camels.
20.Pentecostal: Rebekah works hard to water all the camels.
20.Episcopalian/Anglican: Describes Rebekah's diligent actions in quickly drawing enough water for all ten camels.
20.Orthodox: Details Rebekah's prompt and laborious effort in watering all the camels.
20.Other: So she quickly emptied her jar into the trough, ran back to the well to draw more water, and drew enough for all his camels.
